Award.AwardTitle: IRES: U.S.-Ghana Collaboration Providing Opportunities for Global Research Activities on Sustainable Water Purification (GRA-SWP)
Award.AbstractNarration:
Technical Description
This U.S.-Ghana International Research Experience for Students (IRES) award supports collaboration in water resources science between Southern University, LA and the Kwame Nkrumah University of Science and Technology, Kumasi (KNUST). This IRES project establishes a joint effort between the STEM faculty at these institutions, who will undertake effective, innovative, and transformative research that ensures the sustainability of global water resources and large-scale water purification.

The US-investigative team consists of two faculty members from the Dept. of Mechanical Engineering at Southern University and A&M College, the nation's largest Historically Black College and University; the international participants are faculty members of the Department of Materials Engineering at KUNST. KNUST is the host institution for this IRES project and will facilitate arrangements to enable successful research, scholarly visits, and access to the research laboratories for IRES students. Five faculty members from Southern and Kwame Nkrumah will be directly involved in the research and mentoring activities. Student participants from the U.S. include five undergraduate and one graduate student for five weeks each year over three years. This project will train the next generation of researchers and contribute to developing a globally- engaged workforce.

This project seeks to develop a low cost but technologically efficient composite material for sustainable water purification. It will examine the process of adsorption of the fluoride and other microbial contaminants onto the composite material developed for enhanced fluoride removal. Three separate research tracts that students can choose are: 1) Characterization of fundamental micro-structural properties of laterite, 2) Evaluation of a composite Laterite with alumina and magnesium oxide nano-particles to enhance adsorption of fluoride, and 3) Evaluation of a composite laterite with calcium oxide and silica nano-particles to enhance adsorption of fluoride.
Students will learn data acquisition techniques and the ability to analyze and interpret scientific information.

Broader Description
Students majoring in STEM fields will have the opportunity to engage in research in an international environment where they will have to adapt to solving non-traditional problems.
Additionally, the IRES experience is expected to: 1) enhance US-student global awareness and perspectives, 2) provide experiential learning opportunities for students through multidisciplinary
and multi-institutional partnerships; 3) enhance the ability of water resources science faculty to conduct collaborative research through international engagements. The project will raise
general awareness about related issues and the need and advantages of studying the topics
in multidisciplinary and internationally collaborative environments. The research findings will be disseminated through peer-reviewed publications and presentations at conferences organized by the World Health Organization and the American Society of Civil Engineering.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Overview: Southern University and A&M College (SU) in collaboration with Kwame Nkrumah University of Science and Technology (KNUST) and supported by the National Science Foundation International Research Experiences for Students (NSF IRES) established the IRES: U.S. Ghana Collaboration Providing Opportunities for Global Research Activities on Sustainable Water Purification (GRA-SWP). This research and educational thrust focused on scientific understanding and development a low cost, but technologically efficient composite material filtration system for sustainable water purification in the Bongo Region of Ghana and associated educational activities that provided undergraduate students and traditionally underrepresented minority (URM) students in the Science, Technology, Engineering and Mathematics (STEM) with excellent educational and training opportunities.   This research provided four tracts for students: i) Characterization of fundamental microstructural properties of laterite, ii) Development of a composite Laterite with alumina and magnesium oxide nanoparticles to enhance adsorptivity of fluoride, iii) Evaluation of a composite laterite with calcium oxide and silica nanoparticles for in situ adsorption of fluoride, and iv) Design and test of column filtration system for field implementation.

The Intellectual Merit of the GRA-SWP is exemplified by: (1) Synthesized a laterite-alumina composite (LAC) material for removal of fluoride from groundwater. (2) We characterized the fundamental phase distribution properties of the raw laterite and LAC using scanning electron microscope (SEM) and X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns which showed  adherence of  alumina to mainly  iron oxide phases.(3) Established that the adsorption characteristics of LAC was not significantly affected in the pH range of 6-9 that would make suitable for processing drinking water. (4) Development of Kinetic model for evaluation of LAC.  (5) Conducted Fixed-column design and experimentation studies on remediation of fluoride-contaminated water using developed LAC at KNUST. Overall, we developed a low cost, but technologically efficient composite material, indigenous to the region for filtration of excess fluoride from water below the UN benchmark of 1.5mg/l, and succeeded in developing a prototype system utilizing LAC that would aid in providing potable water to the Bongo District.

Broader Impacts:

Publications: One peer-reviewed manuscript to Journal of Environmental Chemistry under review for publication, four conference proceedings extended abstracts and one PhD Dissertation. 

Products: GRA-SWP IRES directly supported 22 students and has impacted over 15 international graduate students through research experiences, intellectual sharing and presentations at conferences. Three faculty researchers at SU were engaged in this project. Seventeen of the supported students were from SU, two from University of Arkansas, Fayetteville, one from Xavier University, New Orleans, one from University of Maryland Baltimore County, and one from University of Oklahoma, (19 were undergraduates and three were graduate students). Of the GRA-SWP total, 20 were African American; 12 were women. Of the 12 women, 11 were African American of whom two were master's students. The disciplines impacted are Mechanical Engineering, Civil Engineering, Chemistry, Biology, Physics, Animal Science, Plant Science, Engineering Masters, Environmental Toxicology, and Urban Forestry. 

Students admitted into Graduate Programs: Erica Dasi (PhD program at University of Southern Florida), Lamar Burton (PhD program at Florida International University), Kimberly Cribbs (MS degree from King Abdullah University of Science and Technology Saudi Arabia), Kristen Hypolite (PhD program at Southern University and A&M College).

Leveraging IRES Resources with other NSF Projects: GRA-SWP collaborated with the following SU NSF funded projects: 1) Next Generation CREST Composites Center at SU;   2) HBCU-Achieving Competitiveness and Excellence (ACE) Program; and 3) NSF CREST Next Generation Multi-functional Composites Phase 2.

Courses developed and taught: IRES students completed a three credits course, Principles of Sustainability, (ENGR 201).

Outreach Activities includes presentations to Master of Engineering program seminar and Environmental Toxicology PhD program seminar in the College of Sciences and Engineering. Five SU IRES students participated in regional and international conferences.

Kimberly Cribbs from the first IRES cohort received several international travel awards to present her IRES research at conferences:

  •  The 2nd International Conference on Recent Developments in Science, Engineering and Technology REDSET-2015, New Delhi, India, 
  • The King Abdullah University of Science and Technology research poster competition in Saudi Arabia in 2015,
  • Emerging Researchers National (ERN) Conference Washington, DC 2016. Kimberly was a finalist for the prestigious Gates Cambridge Scholarship. She is now employed at the North Carolina Department of Environmental Quality.

Lamar Burton, (2015 cohort) won first place in the undergraduate poster session at the First Annual Wilbur B. Clarke Chemistry Symposium held at SU in fall semester 2015.

Kristen Hypolite (2015 cohort) presented at the 2016 ERN. Erica Dasi (2016 cohort) won a 2nd place award for her research presentation at the 2017 ERN. Erica is GEM scholarship recipient. Jaylen Scott (2017 cohort) also  presented at the 2018 ERN.

Dissemination of Outputs: IRES GRA-SWP disseminated activities through the SU active website, and social media outlets such as Facebook, Twitter, and YouTube. The IRES project principal investigators have attended and presented at four international conferences with acclaimed research presentations for the work done.
